awd_titl_txt: Workshop Proposal on Replication, Reproducibility, and the Use of Data Assets in Advancing the Frontiers of Science in Education Research--the Critical Role of Journals
awd_abstract_narration:
Replication and reproducibility are critically important tenets of the scientific process.  Yet, many fields including education research struggle to regularly support and publish results from replication studies.  Although important strides have been made to ensure that more scientific data is available, substantive challenges remain with respect to making data from important publications widely available in a timely manner. 

This conference proposal will bring together journal editors and early career researchers in education research to discuss issues related to open science including, replication, reproducibility, and data sharing related to the publication process. This 2-3 day conference that will help to develop a fuller understanding of the principles and purposes of journals in the data sharing process, consider the role of journals in publishing replication research, broaden knowledge about the mechanisms for sharing data and cultivating replication research,  and provide early career scholars with opportunities to play a critical role in replicating and reproducing research findings via open access to data.

por.por_cntn:
The workshop, Data Sharing and Research Transparency at the Article Publishing Stage, held on July 25 - 27, 2017 in Washington, DC, aimed to initiate an essential conversation about the importance of data sharing for the replication and reproducibility of research results and for the further advancement of knowledge. The emphasis on journal publishing reflects the fact that it is the logical and most appropriate point to share data. By this time, articles have been peer reviewed, further attesting to the quality of the published research before dissemination.  Also, the point when authors submit manuscripts for publication, they typically have datasets and other research-related products (e.g., code books, program scripts on which the analysis is based) in a clean and final form.

The focus of the workshop was on journal editors and early career education scientists drawn from the major research associations in education research and the learning sciences. With funding from the National Science Foundation, the conference brought together more than 60 participants including editors from 18 journals and 17 early career scholars representing 13 scientific societies; invited experts, association leaders, and federal officials to address data sharing and research transparency in education research and to consider how it can advance scientific knowledge.

Intellectual Merit:

The workshop provided ample opportunity for discussion and dialogue in plenary and breakout sessions. A key issue and point of emphasis throughout the workshop was the commitment to building knowledge in a process that is transparent and well-warranted and that can lead to new contributions. A significant takeaway from the discussions was that sharing data is an essential part of science. Sharing data lends legitimacy and credibility in making knowledge claims, and provides the proof and the basis for how we know what we know.

The workshop also focused attention on data archives as mediators of open data sharing, on best practices and guidance for ethical data sharing and responsible data use, and on model guidelines for data sharing at the article publishing stage. Representatives from data repositories including, the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR), Databrary, the Qualitative Data Repository (QDR), and the Center for Open Science (COS) provided insights and information on managing and protecting data in safe and secure environments.  Federal officials discussed federal initiatives to incentivize data sharing and research replication, and emphasized the importance of strong data management plans in funding applications.

Breakout sessions included consideration of data sharing strategies for different types of data, issues of significance for editors and early career scholars (in separate breakout sessions), and next steps for participating associations to consider together as well as within their home associations.  

 A key outcome of this project is the formal resolution that issued from the workshop. At the conclusion of the workshop, participants unanimously adopted a consensus resolution which included a commitment to transparent reporting of research; responsible sharing and use of data; and the value of diverse contexts, methods, and modes of inquiry to advance education knowledge and serve the public good. Participants determined to continue to work within and across their research associations to cultivate wider knowledge of these issues and inspire our research communities to achieve their highest ideals.

 Broad Impacts:

The project thus far has produced a successful workshop, a consensus resolution, and a consideration of issues and substantive recommendations related to data sharing and research transparency. Participants at the workshop are committed to reporting back to their associations and continuing work through their associations to cultivate wider knowledge about these issues. During 2018 and early 2019, PI Levine gave presentations, and organized or participated in over a dozen additional sessions on open science, data sharing, research transparency, and the responsible conduct of research. She also helped others from participating societies with their presentations or meetings.

Professional development was a key part of this workshop. The explicit inclusion of 17 early career scholars provided both their perspectives and a professional development opportunity for them. Follow-up activities will include workshops, webinars, and other training opportunities on best practices in sharing, using, and acknowledging data as well as in reporting, publishing, and communicating research.

A culture of research transparency and data sharing has direct benefits to society and to participants in research. Data sharing, access, and use allow for more robust study of phenomena (important to all fields of science), including education research. This project is expected to be catalytic in further providing associations and journals in education research with relevant information, strategies, and tools for making change. Working with associations and editors on a community project (like this important one) can have a multiplier effect larger than anything that AERA or NSF can do alone.
